Award.AwardTitle: The influence of plant functional traits on ecosystem responses to altered rainfall
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the coming decades, ecological communities will experience numerous environmental changes, including shifting climates and invasion by exotic species. Plant and microbial communities may exhibit non-linear responses to these environmental changes as species encounter physiological thresholds that constrain their growth and reproduction. Ultimately, ecosystem responses to environmental change will depend both on short-term shifts in species physiology or growth, and long-term shifts in species composition. This project will help develop the understanding of ecosystem responses to environmental change that will be needed for sustainable long term management of chaparral ecosystems.

Experimental, observational, and modeling approaches will be used to quantify chaparral ecosystem responses to altered rainfall regimes. Rainout shelters will be used to produce a gradient of rainfall quantity, and initial species composition of the experimental plots will be controlled by removing invasive annual grasses. Short-term physiological measurements will be taken on focal species, which will also be monitored over the course of the experiment to measure growth and survival. To complement these experiments, similar measurements will be taken on dominant plant species along a natural rainfall gradient across Southern California. Results from these experiments and surveys will be used to parameterize a Dynamic Global Vegetation Model to predict how predicted shifts in rainfall regimes will influence plant species composition and, ultimately, influence regional ecosystem processes.

This project will contribute to undergraduate, graduate, and public education, it will provide data to the broader scientific community, and it will inform land-management agencies. The experiment will provide research opportunities both for undergraduate and graduate students. Further, the research will evaluate how invasion influences ecosystem responses to global change, and whether interannual variation in rainfall may create opportunities for native shrub restoration. Communicating these findings with relevant conservation and land-management organizations will be one of the most important outcomes from this experiment. Finally, the project will make all of the data available and support communication about the ecological impacts of global change through evening lectures in public venues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, scientists have discovered that semi-arid ecosystems have a large influence on interannual variation in the global carbon cycle. In these systems, herbaceous and woody plants represent two ends of a functional spectrum, with herbaceous species having high potential for fast growth, while woody species grow more slowly but also use resources (such as water) more efficiently. Exotic herbaceous species are increasingly invading the historically shrub-dominated ecosystems of Southern California, and are also invading other Mediterranean-type ecosystem worldwide. Our study showed that these native, woody shrubs are more drought-tolerant than the invasive herbaceous species, and hence that invasion and drought act synergistically to lower carbon capture potential at the ecosystem level. Invasion in this system also lowers ecosystem carbon storage by accelerating litter decomposition rates. Although invasive species declined with drought, we found they recovered quickly when rainfall amounts rose to normal levels in a subsequent year, indicating that population-level processes, such as emergence from the seed bank, are critical for estimating interannual variation in ecosystem carbon capture in invaded systems such as this one. Altogether, the results of this work are contributing to a more general understanding of carbon cycling responses to shifting soil moisture availability in semi-arid ecosystems.

The research supported by this grant also had broader impacts for training the next generation of scientists, outreach to non-profit and governmental land management groups, and public outreach. For instance, trainees on this award included six PhD students, two MS students, eight undergraduate researchers from UC San Diego, and three staff technicians. Three undergraduate students also came from other institutions to participate in summer research through the UC San Diego STARS program (Summer Training Academy for Research Success), a program aimed at promoting research and professional development opportunities for traditionally under-represented minorities in STEM. Trainees have also been involved K-12 educational programs, for instance in partnership with the UC San Diego School of Pharmacy with a summer research program for high school students focused on pharmacological prospecting from California native plants.

Outreach activities have included public seminars and hikes associated with the San Diego Natural History Museum, and natural history tours in the University of California Natural Reserves. We have also engaged with local land managers and institutions such as the U.S. Fish and Wildlife service to develop effective strategies to restore native shrubs in Southern California. Finally, this project has made an impact on public science literacy. By engaging citizens and K-12 students the natural history of their surroundings we are able to impart specific information about the interplay of plant species and their environmental context, as well as demonstrate how the scientific process proceeds.
